title: Python Fundamentals: Variables, Functions, and Loops
description: An introductory course on Python's core programming concepts including data types, function creation, and iteration patterns.
learning_goal: Master Python variables, functions, and loops to build simple programs.
expected_knowledge: Dynamic typing and built-in data types in Python
How to define and call functions with parameters
For loop and while loop mechanics
expected_skills: Declare variables and perform type conversions
Write functions with default parameters and return values
Implement loops with break and continue

modules.title: Variables and Types
modules.description: Understanding how Python stores and manages data through variables.
modules.learning_goal: Learn variable assignment, data types, and type conversion in Python.
expected_knowledge: Core types: str, int, float, bool, None

concepts.title: Variable Assignment
concepts.definition: Creating a named reference to a value using the = operator.

concepts.title: Dynamic Typing in Python
concepts.definition: Python determines variable types at runtime based on assigned values.

exercises.description: Create variables of types str, int, float, and bool. Print each variable's type.
exercises.reference_solution:
s = 'hi'
i = 5
f = 3.14
b = True
for v in [s, i, f, b]: print(type(v))
exercises.grading_criteria: Four variables created with correct types.

concepts.title: Python Data Types
concepts.definition: The fundamental types: str, int, float, bool, and NoneType.

concepts.title: Type Conversion Functions
concepts.definition: Built-in functions int(), str(), float() convert values between types.

exercises.description: Convert the string '123' to an integer, double it, convert back to string, and print.

modules.title: Functions in Python
modules.description: Defining reusable code blocks with parameters and return values.

concepts.title: Function Definition with def
concepts.definition: Functions are defined with the def keyword, a name, parameters, and a colon.

concepts.title: Default Parameter Values
concepts.definition: Parameters can have default values, making them optional when calling.

exercises.description: Write a function power(base, exp=2) that returns base raised to exp.
exercises.reference_solution:
def power(base, exp=2):
    return base ** exp
print(power(3))
print(power(2, 10))
exercises.grading_criteria: Default parameter works; both calls produce correct results.

concepts.title: The return Statement
concepts.definition: return sends a value back to the caller and ends function execution.
examples:
def add(a, b):
    return a + b

exercises.description: Write calculate_average(numbers) returning the mean of a list, or 0 for empty lists.
exercises.grading_criteria: Handles empty list; correct average for non-empty.

modules.title: Loops and Iteration
modules.description: Repeating actions with for and while loops.
modules.learning_goal: Use loop constructs to iterate and control program flow.
expected_knowledge: for loop over sequences and range()

concepts.title: For Loop Basics
concepts.definition: A for loop iterates over items in a sequence, executing the body for each.

concepts.title: Using range()
concepts.definition: range() generates a sequence of numbers for loop iteration.

exercises.description: Print all even numbers from 0 to 20 using a for loop and range().
exercises.grading_criteria: Uses range with step of 2; prints 0 through 20.

concepts.title: While Loop
concepts.definition: A while loop repeats as long as its condition evaluates to True.

concepts.title: Break and Continue
concepts.definition: break exits the loop; continue skips to the next iteration.

exercises.description: Write a function that finds elements common to two lists using a loop.
exercises.grading_criteria: Uses loop; correctly returns shared elements.
